awd_titl_txt: Synthesis: Impact of integrating innovative technologies in STEM classrooms on K-12 students' STEM career outcomes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by engaging in hands-on field experience, laboratory/project-based entrepreneurship tasks and mentorship experiences. The NSF ITEST program supports research on the design, development, implementation, and selective spread of innovative strategies for engaging students in technology-rich experiences

This Miami University project will synthesize research conducted from 2000 to the present regarding the effects of innovative technology-based educational interventions on PreK-12 students' STEM career outcomes. This mixed-method study will include two concurrent, interrelated components—a quantitative meta-analysis and a qualitative synthesis. The goal of the project is to provide a more complete understanding of rigorous intervention research regarding the effects on students' STEM career outcomes. The research team will analyze variations in effect sizes among intervention characteristics, learning contexts, student demographics, and study designs. This study will provide insights regarding what types of interventions work best for which student populations, in what educational settings, and within what community contexts.

The quantitative meta-analysis component of this project will provide a comprehensive picture of the ways interventions using innovative technologies and technology-based learning experiences influence PreK-12 students' STEM career outcomes, directly or indirectly, to identify intervention characteristics that offer the most evidence of effectiveness for impacting STEM career development overall, and specifically, for students traditionally underserved in STEM education and underrepresented in STEM careers. Qualitative synthesis will supplement findings about magnitudes and variations of effects with findings that 1) help explain how and why intervention characteristics influence career outcomes for different types of students and 2) further develop theoretical constructs that reflect underrepresented groups' STEM career development trajectories in culturally appropriate ways. Methodologic features of this proposed study will include: (a) comprehensive review of quantitative and qualitative, peer-reviewed and gray literature, 2000 to present; (b) use of a broad definition of "career-related outcomes" to theoretically link effects, variables, and moderators to more proximal, measurable career outcomes; (c) study of a broad range of innovative technology interventions; (d) searching, screening, coding, analyzing, and synthesizing processes following rigorous, systematic review guidelines; (e) consideration of relevant moderator variables and interactions among variables to identify critical intervention features and settings associated with positive outcomes; and (f) control of study rigor and publication biases. By synthesizing quantitative and qualitative components at a meta-level, this study will provide a model of scholarly review that is replicable across fields for other studies of program-level impacts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This mixed-methods synthesis study utilized a meta-analysis and a qualitative synthesis to examine the impact of integrating innovative technologies in STEM education on Grades K-12 students’ STEM career-related outcomes. The research team conducted two rounds of database searches and an additional search through STELAR (STEM Learning and Research Center) resources to extract research publications related to this topic. After reviewing 9,254 publications, the research team identified 107 primary studies that reported students’ STEM career-related outcomes following participation in an educational intervention or program that integrated innovative technologies, such as information and communication technology, engineering and design, and integrated STEM curriculum. These studies were published as peer-reviewed journal articles, doctoral dissertations, research and evaluation reports, conference proceedings, or other types of publications between 2000 and 2023. Of these, 71 studies were included in the meta-analysis and 40 were included in the qualitative synthesis, with 4 included in both research components.

 

Overall, findings from the meta-analysis suggest that integrating innovative technologies and teaching strategies into formal and informal STEM education has shown a significantly positive impact on elementary and secondary students’ STEM career outcomes. Collectively, these interventions had a larger impact on changes in students’ knowledge of STEM careers than on changes in their interest in pursuing STEM careers in the future. However, the sizes of these impacts varied greatly across studies. The research team investigated various participant, intervention, and study characteristics but did not find strong connections between any of them and the variations across study outcomes.

 

The qualitative synthesis linked participation in technology-driven education programs with six STEM career development trajectories, namely STEM career Supported, Influenced, Informed, Enriched, Humanized, and Clarified trajectories. Specifically:

  • 48% of the studies reported sustained interest in STEM careers among students who began the intervention with STEM career interest (Supported).
  • 45% of the studies reported increased interest in STEM careers directly linked to participation in the intervention (Influenced).
  • 40% of the studies reported students having increased understanding, awareness, and knowledge about the nature of STEM careers, as well as the relevance of STEM to non-STEM careers (Informed).
  • 33% of the studies reported enjoyment or career-related benefits resulting from participation in the intervention without an increase in STEM career interest or participation among students with little or no STEM career interest at the beginning of the intervention (Enriched).
  • 15% of the studies, particularly those targeting students from underrepresented and underserved backgrounds, reported interest in STEM careers that students connected to their desire to help people or to the ability to interact with STEM professionals who shared identity characteristics (e.g., gender) during the intervention (Humanized).
  • 10% of the studies reported abandoned interest in STEM careers after an intervention among students who began with STEM or unsure career interests (Clarified).

 

Cross-examination of findings from the meta-analysis and qualitative synthesis suggests that a variety of innovative, technology-driven intervention approaches are capable of supporting K-12 students’ career development in positive ways. Across studies, the use of authentic scientific lab or field equipment and engagement of students in authentic scientific investigation or engineering design inquiry were associated with increased interest in STEM careers.

 

This study advances a perspective that expands the conception of STEM career outcomes beyond awareness and interest to include the ways interventions humanize STEM careers for K-12 students, help them clarify their career expectations, and benefit students in ways that are valuable for individual learning or career development but are not likely to result in STEM career entry. Findings from this study may help program developers design future programs, and researchers design future studies more precisely focused on the outcomes they expect in relation to the types of participants they will serve. Policy-makers should work together with the STEM education research community to facilitate opportunities for longitudinal engagement of students in STEM programming coupled with longitudinal research programs to better study the effects of engagement in STEM experiences on actual STEM career entry.

 

Additionally, during the process of conducting this research study, the research team facilitated the academic growth of four graduate student research assistants who served as reviewers or coders for this project. The project resulted in a number of conference presentations and one manuscript.
